content:
TITLE: Parsing and Rendering MJML in Rust DESCRIPTION: This Rust code snippet demonstrates the complete process of parsing MJML input and rendering it to HTML using the `mrml` crate. It showcases the use of the `parse` and `render` methods, including error handling for both parsing and rendering. Dependencies include the `mrml` crate, and the input is a valid MJML string. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: rust CODE: ``` use mrml::prelude::render::RenderOptions; // Needed for default render options let mjml_input = r#" Hello World! "#; // 1. Parse the MJML (from Chapter 1) match mrml::parse(mjml_input) { Ok(parsed_mjml) => { println!("MJML parsed successfully!"); // 2. Define rendering options (we'll use defaults for now) let render_options = RenderOptions::default(); // 3. Call the render method match parsed_mjml.render(&render_options) { Ok(final_html) => { // If rendering is successful, we get the final HTML string! println!("MJML rendered successfully!"); println!("--- Output HTML (simplified) ---"); // The actual output is much longer due to email client compatibility HTML println!("{}", final_html); } Err(e) => { // Handle potential rendering errors (less common than parse errors) println!("Oops, couldn't render the MJML: {:?}", e); } } } Err(e) => { println!("Oops, couldn't parse the MJML: {:?}", e); } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rendering MJML to HTML using MRML CLI DESCRIPTION: These commands use the `mrml-cli` tool to render an MJML file (`welcome.mjml`) into HTML. The first command prints the generated HTML to the console, while the second command saves the HTML to a file named `welcome.html`. Requires `mrml-cli` to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # Render welcome.mjml and print HTML to the console mrml-cli welcome.mjml render # Render welcome.mjml and save HTML to welcome.html mrml-cli welcome.mjml render -o welcome.html ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rendering MJML in Python using mrml-python DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet demonstrates how to use the `mrml-python` package to render an MJML string into HTML. It imports the `mrml` library, defines an MJML string, and then calls the `mrml.to_html()` function to render it. The resulting HTML and any warnings are then printed to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import mrml mjml_string = """ Hello from Python! """ # Render the MJML string to HTML result = mrml.to_html(mjml_string) # Check for warnings (more on warnings later) if result.warnings: print("Warnings:", result.warnings) # Access the rendered HTML content html_output = result.content print(html_output[:100] + "...") # Print the first 100 chars ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rendering MJML in Node.js using mrml-wasm DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code snippet demonstrates how to use the `mrml-wasm` package in a Node.js environment to render an MJML string into HTML. It imports the `Engine` class from the `mrml-wasm/node/mrml` module, creates an instance of the engine, and then calls the `toHtmlAsync()` method to render the MJML string asynchronously. The resulting HTML and any warnings are then printed to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Use the Node.js-specific entry point const { Engine } = require("mrml-wasm/node/mrml"); const mjmlString = ` Hello from WASM! `; // Create an engine instance const engine = new Engine(); // Render the MJML string to HTML // Note: In WASM, rendering might be async depending on features used engine.toHtmlAsync(mjmlString).then(result => { if (result.warnings && result.warnings.length > 0) { console.warn("Warnings:", result.warnings); } const htmlOutput = result.content; console.log(htmlOutput.substring(0, 100) + "..."); // Print start of HTML }).catch(error => { console.error("Rendering failed:", error); }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parsing and Rendering MJML with LocalIncludeLoader Using Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates configuring mrml's Python binding to use a LocalIncludeLoader that loads included MJML files from the local filesystem. It sets up ParserOptions with the loader pointing to a base directory and invokes the to_html function with MJML content containing tags. The output is rendered HTML with included partials injected. Prerequisites include having your MJML partials present in the filesystem relative to the base directory. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import mrml import os # Needed for file paths # Assume main_email.mjml, partials/header.mjml, partials/footer.mjml # exist in the current directory structure. main_mjml_content = """ Welcome to our service! """ # Tell the loader where to look for files (e.g., the current directory) # Paths in will be relative to this directory. base_dir = os.getcwd() loader_options = mrml.local_loader(base_dir) # Configure the parser to use this loader parser_opts = mrml.ParserOptions(include_loader=loader_options) # Parse and render result = mrml.to_html(main_mjml_content, parser_options=parser_opts) print("Rendered HTML (includes header and footer):") print(result.content[:200] + "...") # Show the beginning of the HTML ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring ParserOptions with Include Loader in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to instantiate `mrml.ParserOptions` and assign a configured `include_loader` (specifically a `local_loader`). This object is then used when calling `mrml.to_html` to control how the parser resolves `` directives during the MJML parsing phase. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import mrml import os # Example: Setting up a local include loader (like in Chapter 5) base_dir = os.getcwd() loader_opts = mrml.local_loader(base_dir) # Create ParserOptions and specify the include_loader parser_options = mrml.ParserOptions( include_loader=loader_opts ) # We would pass 'parser_options' when calling mrml.to_html() # mjml_input = "..." # result = mrml.to_html(mjml_input, parser_options=parser_options) # print("Parser configured!") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring RenderOptions and Rendering MJML in Python DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates creating and configuring `mrml.RenderOptions` by setting `disable_comments` to `True` and defining a custom font (`MyCustomFont`) via the `fonts` dictionary. The configured `render_options` object is then passed to `mrml.to_html` alongside the MJML input, influencing the structure and content of the generated HTML. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import mrml mjml_input = """ My Configured Email Hello! """ # Create RenderOptions render_options = mrml.RenderOptions( # Switch 1: Remove HTML comments from the output disable_comments=True, # Switch 2: Define default fonts to include in the # (Keys are font names, values are URLs to the font file) fonts={ "MyCustomFont": "url-to-your-custom-font.woff2" # Default fonts like 'Ubuntu' are usually included unless overridden } # Another option: social_icon_origin="https://custom.icons/url/" ) # Render the MJML using these options # (We'll use default parser options here for simplicity) result = mrml.to_html(mjml_input, render_options=render_options) print("Rendered HTML (with comments disabled and custom font defined):") # Check the output HTML: the comment should be gone, # and the should include a @font-face for MyCustomFont. print(result.content[:500] + "...") # Show the beginning of the HTML ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example MJML Template Using for File-Based Partial Templates DESCRIPTION: This MJML markup demonstrates how to use the tag to modularize email templates by referencing external header and footer partials. The main template references header and footer mjml files stored under a filesystem path, promoting reusability and maintainability of template components. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: mjml CODE: ``` Welcome to our service! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parsing MJML Example DESCRIPTION: This Rust code snippet demonstrates how to use the `mrml::parse()` function to parse an MJML string. It takes an MJML template as input, calls the parse function, and handles potential parsing errors using a `match` statement. The primary output is a success or error message. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: rust CODE: ``` // The MJML template we want to parse let mjml_input = r#" Hello World! "#; // Call the parse function match mrml::parse(mjml_input) { Ok(parsed_mjml) => { // If parsing is successful, we get the structured representation back. // We don't need to look inside `parsed_mjml` just yet, // just know that mrml now understands the template! println!("MJML parsed successfully!"); // Next step would be rendering (covered later) } Err(e) => { // If there's an error in the MJML syntax... println!("Oops, couldn't parse the MJML: {:?}", e); } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parsing and Rendering MJML with MemoryIncludeLoader Using Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use mrml's MemoryIncludeLoader in Python to supply MJML partials directly from in-memory strings rather than filesystem files. It configures ParserOptions with a dictionary mapping file keys to MJML content and parses a main MJML template that includes these keys. This approach suits scenarios where templates come from a database or configuration rather than disk storage. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import mrml main_mjml_content = """ Main content. """ # Store the content of our "files" in a dictionary in_memory_files = { "my_header": "Memory Header", "my_footer": "Memory Footer" } # Create a memory loader with this data loader_options = mrml.memory_loader(in_memory_files) # Configure the parser parser_opts = mrml.ParserOptions(include_loader=loader_options) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example MJML template DESCRIPTION: This is a simple MJML template that defines a basic email structure with a section, column, and text element. It's used as input for the `mrml-cli` tool to generate HTML. The root element is ``, and it contains `` with nested components. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: mjml CODE: ``` Welcome to mrml! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example MJML Input for Render Options Demonstration DESCRIPTION: This MJML snippet serves as input for the subsequent Python code demonstrating `RenderOptions`. It includes an HTML comment and a reference to a custom font family (`MyCustomFont`), which are used to show the effects of setting `disable_comments` and `fonts` in `RenderOptions`. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: mjml CODE: ``` My Configured Email Hello! ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Conceptual RenderOptions Structure and Default in Rust DESCRIPTION: This conceptual Rust snippet shows the basic structure of `RenderOptions`, including fields for `disable_comments`, `social_icon_origin`, and `fonts`. It also illustrates the `impl Default for RenderOptions` block, indicating how sensible default values are provided for these rendering settings when the options are not explicitly configured. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: rust CODE: ``` // Simplified concept - Not the actual mrml code! use std::collections::HashMap; // Options for the rendering phase #[derive(Debug, Clone)] // Allows copying the options pub struct RenderOptions { // Should HTML comments be stripped out? pub disable_comments: bool, // Custom URL prefix for social icons pub social_icon_origin: Option, // Map of font-family names to their CSS src URLs pub fonts: HashMap, // Other rendering settings... } // Function to provide sensible defaults impl Default for RenderOptions { fn default() -> Self { // Sets default values like keeping comments, default fonts map, etc. Self { disable_comments: false, social_icon_origin: None, fonts: default_fonts(), // A helper function to get default fonts // ... } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Conceptual ParserOptions Structure Definition in Rust DESCRIPTION: This conceptual Rust snippet illustrates the basic structure of `ParserOptions` within the `mrml-core` library. It shows that the primary component is a `Box`, which is used by the parser to handle `` directives during the parsing process. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: rust CODE: ``` // Simplified concept - Not the actual mrml code! use crate::prelude::parser::loader::IncludeLoader; // Link to IncludeLoader trait // Options for the parsing phase pub struct ParserOptions { // The configured assistant for handling pub include_loader: Box, // Potentially other parser-specific options in the future... } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing MRML Python package with pip DESCRIPTION: This command installs the mrml-python package using pip, Python's package installer. It fetches the package from PyPI and installs it into your Python environment, allowing you to import and use the `mrml` library in your Python scripts. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install mrml-python ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing MRML CLI tool with Cargo DESCRIPTION: This command installs the mrml-cli tool using Cargo, Rust's package manager. It downloads and compiles the mrml-cli crate and places the executable in your Cargo bin directory, allowing you to use the `mrml-cli` command in your terminal. Requires Rust and Cargo to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` cargo install --locked mrml-cli ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing MRML WASM package with npm DESCRIPTION: This command installs the mrml-wasm package using npm, the Node.js package manager. It downloads the package and its dependencies from the npm registry and installs them into your project's `node_modules` directory. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` npm install mrml-wasm # or yarn add mrml-wasm ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simplified MjText Component Structure in Rust DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a conceptual representation of how an MJML component is stored as a Rust struct in mrml. The struct contains fields for attributes and content, along with a rendering method that transforms the component data into HTML output. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: rust CODE: ``` // Simplified concept - Not the actual mrml code! struct MjText { // Attributes are stored as fields attributes: MjTextAttributes, // Holds things like color, font-size, padding content: String, // The actual text, e.g., "Hello World!" // ... other necessary internal data ... } // A helper struct to hold the attributes specifically struct MjTextAttributes { color: Option, // Optional, might not be set font_size: Option, padding: Option, // ... many more attributes ... } // Each component struct also has associated functions (methods) // that contain the logic for rendering. impl MjText { // Simplified idea of the rendering function // (We'll cover rendering properly in the next chapter!) fn render(&self /* , other context info */) -> String { // Logic to generate HTML for mj-text using // self.attributes.color, self.content, etc. // This involves creating
s or s with specific inline CSS. let html_output = format!( "
{}
", self.attributes.color.as_deref().unwrap_or("#000000"), // Use default if not set self.attributes.padding.as_deref().unwrap_or("10px 25px"), self.content ); // The real logic is much more complex! return html_output; } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: MJML to Internal Representation Mapping Flow Diagram DESCRIPTION: A Mermaid diagram visualizing how MJML input is parsed and transformed into internal component representations. It shows the flow from raw MJML text to the creation of specific Rust struct instances with their attributes, content, and rendering logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: mermaid CODE: ``` graph LR A["MJML Input:
Hi"] -- Parsing (Chapter 1) --> B(Internal Representation); subgraph B [Internal Representation] direction LR C[Specific Rust Struct:
MjText Instance] C --> D{Attributes:
color: "red"
padding: *default*} C --> E[Content:
"Hi"] C --> F[Rendering Logic:
Defined in MjText struct] end style B fill:#eee,stroke:#333,stroke-width:1px ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Header Partial MJML Template for Inclusion DESCRIPTION: Defines a reusable header partial used with the tag, containing a section with a logo image. This snippet is intended to be stored separately and referenced from other templates for consistent branding. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: mjml CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Footer Partial MJML Template for Inclusion DESCRIPTION: Defines a reusable footer partial with company copyright and unsubscribe links, designed to be included in other MJML templates for uniformity across emails. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: mjml CODE: ``` Â© 2023 Your Company Unsubscribe ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Visualizing mrml Binding Flow with Mermaid Sequence Diagram DESCRIPTION: This mermaid sequence diagram illustrates the cross-platform bindings workflow for the mrml engine. It shows how user input (from CLI, Python, or JavaScript) passes through the binding interfaces to the Rust core engine where MJML parsing and rendering occurs, and the results propagate back to the user. This visualization serves to clarify the interactions and data conversions between different layers of the mrml ecosystem. SOURCE: https://github.com/6p5ra/mrml-documentation/blob/main/files/mrml.md#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: mermaid CODE: ``` sequenceDiagram participant User as User (CLI/Python/JS) participant Binding as Binding (mrml-cli / mrml-python / mrml-wasm) participant MrmlCore as mrml-core (Rust Engine) User->>Binding: Provides MJML input & calls function (e.g., render) Binding->>MrmlCore: Calls parse() with MJML string MrmlCore->>MrmlCore: Parses MJML into internal structure MrmlCore-->>Binding: Returns parsed structure (or error) alt Parsing Successful Binding->>MrmlCore: Calls render() on parsed structure MrmlCore->>MrmlCore: Generates HTML based on structure MrmlCore-->>Binding: Returns HTML string (or error) Binding-->>User: Returns final HTML (or error) else Parsing Failed Binding-->>User: Returns parse error end ```
